intro: Calendula versicolor, commonly known as the variable calendula, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, brightly colored flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves and vibrant yellow to orange petals that change color as the flowers mature. Calendula versicolor thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for gardeners seeking ornamental and medicinal plants. Its flowers are used in herbal remedies and as natural dyes due to their high pigment content.
